To avoid confusion with the Screw Theory/Featherstone-style definition of wrench, in  which a the linear part of the “wrench” expressed in the world frame applied to a given body is considered to be applied to point of the body instantaneously coincident with the world origin, I suggest to explicitly mentions the application point of the force \(that I guess is the link com, but I am not sure about\)

This Screw Theory/Featherstone-style wrench definition may seem be strange at first, but it is actually the original definition of the word “wrench” in multibody dynamics context, and is actually extremely used in robotics, for example it is the definition used in Chapter 3 “Dynamics” of the Springer Handbook of Robotics [https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9783319325507](https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9783319325507) , and if I a not wrong in Dart itself \( [https://github.com/dartsim/dart](https://github.com/dartsim/dart) \).

Furthermore, it would be useful to mention for how long the force added will remain applied on the link. For a single update step?

‌
